facts.text: Six petitions filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution: Nos. 22 to 26 and 42 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petitions Nos. 22 to 26 and 42 of 1959. Petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by AYYANGAR, J. on September 12, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. September 12. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-These six petitions filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution raise for companysideration three points

facts.text: Petitions challenge constitutional validity of Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952 (Act LXXIV of 1952).

anchor.surface_text: These six petitions filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution raise for companysideration three points  1  the companystitutional validity of the operative provisions of the Forward Contracts  Regulation  Act  Act LXXIV of 1952

facts.text: Notification dated February 11, 1959 issued under s.15 of the Act bringing gur within purview with immediate effect.

anchor.surface_text: 2  the validity of a numberification dated February 11, 1959, issued under s. 15 of the Act by which gur was brought within the purview of the enactment with immediate effect,

facts.text: Another notification dated February 11, 1959 fixing price for settlement of forward contracts subsisting on that date.

anchor.surface_text: and  3  the validity of another numberification of the Central Government issued simultaneously fixing the price at which Forward Contracts subsisting on February 11, 1959, was directed to be settled.

facts.text: Petitioner in Petition No. 23 of 1959 is Raghubar Dayal Jai Prakash, a firm carrying on business of purchase and sale of gur at Meerut.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of understanding the points raised and the effect of the impugned numberifications on the rights of the petitioners it is sufficient to refer to the facts of Petition No. 23 of 1959 which is typical of the cases before us. The petitioner-Raghubar Dayal Jai Prakash

facts.text: Petitioner entered into forward contracts of purchase of gur outstanding on February 11, 1959, in relation to 29,600 maunds.

anchor.surface_text: Contracts entered into by him which were outstanding on February 11, 1959, were in relation to 29,600 maunds. While so, Government published a numberification under a. 15 of the Act on February 11, 1959,

facts.text: Petitioner deposited amount as buyer and special margin under bye-laws.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner had entered into forward companytracts of purchase of gur at certain rates and he had also deposited as the buyer the amount as well as the special margin required to be deposited under the bye-laws of this association.

facts.text: Kaisergunj Beopar Co. P Ltd., Meerut formed by traders to regulate forward transactions in gur.

anchor.surface_text: Traders like the petitioner had companybined together to form a companypany registered under the Indian Companies Act under the name Kaisergunj Beopar Co.  P  Ltd., Meerut. The function of this incorporated body was, inter alia, to regulate forward transactions

facts.text: Association not recognized by Central Government under the Act on date of notification.

anchor.surface_text: This association or companypany, however, was number, on the date of the impugned numberification, recognised by the Central Government under the provisions of the Act to which we shall presently advert, in respect of dealings in gur

facts.text: Notification under s.15 made forward contracts in gur illegal and void.

anchor.surface_text: applying the provisions of that section to gur as a result of which the forward companytracts entered into in gur by the petitioner became illegal and void.

facts.text: Transactions deemed closed out on February 11, 1959 at rates specified in notification; petitioner would suffer loss of Rs. 48,000.

anchor.surface_text: The further legal companysequence of the numberification was that the transactions entered into by the petitioner and others situated similarly like him were to be deemed to be closed out on February 11, 1959-the date of the numberification

facts.text: Ban on forward trading in gur imposed by Sugar Gur Future Trading Prohibition Order, 1951 under Essential Supplies Act, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: After the end of the war, a, ban on forward trading in gur was imposed by the Sugar Gur  Future Trading  Prohibition Order, 1951, issued under the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946.

facts.text: Ban removed by notification dated January 7, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: This ban was however removed by a numberification dated January 7, 1954.

facts.text: Forward Markets Commission report in May 1957 recommended recognition of associations and notification under s.15 for gur.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances by their report which was submitted to the Government in May, 1957, they recommended  1  that Government might accord recognition to certain associations after the necessary formalities had been companypleted,

facts.text: Government resolution dated January 17, 1958 decided not to bring gur under the Act for the time being.

anchor.surface_text: The Government however by their resolution dated January 17, 1958, recorded The main recommendations of the Commission are that the regulatory provisions of the Forward Contracts  Regulation  Act, 1952, be applied to gur

facts.text: Gur prices at Hapur rose by 37% from middle of November 1958 to middle of February 1959 due to speculative activity.

anchor.surface_text: For example, the gur prices, at Hapur, rose during the three months from the middle of November to the middle of February 1959, by 37 per cent as companypared to the rise of 0.15 per cent in sugar

facts.text: No associations granted recognition before February 11, 1959; recognitions granted in June 1959.

anchor.surface_text: No associations had been granted recognition before the date of this numberification dated February 11, 1959, but on the same date another numberification was issued by the Government reading

facts.text: Petitioners are members of recognized associations.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners before us are members of these associations-those in Petitions 22, 23 and 25 being members respectively of the three associations named in the numberification extracted above

facts.text: Notification under s.16 fixed closing rates as average of closing rates in forward markets during three months preceding February 11, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers companyferred by clause  a  of section 16 of the said Act the average of the closing rates prevailing in the respective forward markets during the period of three months immediately preceding the date of this numberification,

facts.text: Forward Markets Commission advised application of s.15 to gur on February 11, 1959 due to price situation.

anchor.surface_text: These developments necessitated a reconsideration of the earlier decision to keep the companymodity out of the purview of the Act and the Government of India, on the advice of the Commission, applied section 15 of the Forward Contracts  Regulation Act,
Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

issues.text: the constitutional validity of the operative provisions of the Forward Contracts Regulation Act, Act LXXIV of 1952, to be referred to hereafter as the Act

anchor.surface_text: the constitutional validity of the operative provisions of the Forward Contracts Regulation Act Act LXXIV of 1952 to be referred to hereafter as the Act , 2 the validity

issues.text: whether sections 5, 6 and 10 of the Act infringe the freedom guaranteed by sub-cl. (c) of cl. (1) of Art. 19 of the Constitution

whether on a proper construction of s. 15 of the Act, the existence of a recognised association authorised to regulate dealings in a particular commodity is a prerequisite for the issue of a notification under the section

whether the issue of the notification under s. 15 without a recognised association is constitutionally invalid as an unreasonable restriction on the right of the petitioners to trade and carry on business under Art. 19(1)(g)
whether s. 15 infringes Art. 14 of the Constitution by conferring unguided and arbitrary power upon the Central Government to choose any commodity
whether s. 15 is constitutionally invalid as violating the freedoms guaranteed by sub-cls. (f) and (g) of cl. (1) of Art. 19 due to retrospective invalidation of contracts
whether s. 16 is invalid for excessive delegation or offending Art. 14 by entrusting the Government with arbitrary power to fix prices without guidance

arguments.claim: Sections 5, 6 and 10 of the Act infringe the freedom guaranteed by sub-cl. (c) of cl. (1) of Art. 19 because they interfere with the internal management and functioning of associations

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by Mr. Nambiar, and. in this he was supported by, the other learned Counsel appearing in the case, particularly by Mr. S. T. Desai, that these sections infringed the freedom guaranteed by sub-cl. c of cl. 1 of Art. 19 of the Constitution. Sub-clause c of el. 1 of Art. 19 runs in these terms

arguments.court_reasoning: Restrictions apply only to voluntary recognition; no constitutional right to recognition; regulation of forward trading legitimate

arguments.claim: The freedom under Art.19(1)(c) includes effective functioning of association without state interference except on public order or morality grounds

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution guarantees to every citizen the right to form an association. The only limitation which might legally be imposed on this right to form an association is that set out in cl. 4 of Art. 19, viz., bye-laws which place restrictions based on public order or morality.

arguments.court_reasoning: Cites All India Bank Employees Association; regulation via voluntary associations valid for public interest

arguments.claim: On proper construction of s.15, existence of recognised association is prerequisite for notification under s.15(1)
arguments.court_reasoning: No express or implicit condition precedent; s.17 allows prohibition without association; cannot be defeated by non-formation

arguments.claim: Issue of notification under s.15 without recognised association is unreasonable restriction on right to trade under Art.19(1)(g)
arguments.court_reasoning: Urgency due to price rise justified immediate action; balancing public interest vs individual rights

arguments.claim: s.15 infringes Art.14 by conferring unguided arbitrary power to choose commodity and time
arguments.court_reasoning: Guidance from variable economic factors and expert advice of Forward Markets Commission

arguments.claim: s.15 violates Art.19(1)(f) and (g) due to retrospective invalidation of contracts
arguments.court_reasoning: Retrospective effect not per se unreasonable; no constitutional bar like US contract clause; reasonableness considering public interest

arguments.claim: s.16 invalid for excessive delegation and arbitrary power to fix prices without guidance, violating Art.14
arguments.court_reasoning: Implicit guidance of reasonableness and market factors; analogous to Essential Commodities Act; actual fixation based on 3-month average reasonable

arguments.claim: Provisions of Act valid; ss.5,6,10 do not infringe Art.19(1)(c)
No prerequisite of recognised association for s.15 notification
Notification under s.15 without association reasonable under Art.19(6)

anchor.surface_text: In situations like those here the reasonableness of the restriction has necessarily to be tested by the degree of urgency which required the intervention of Government.

arguments.claim: s.15 does not violate Art.14; power guided
Retrospective operation of s.15 reasonable under Art.19(1)(f),(g)
s.16 not excessive delegation; guided by reasonableness
Forward trading regulation necessary due to speculation risks, as per expert committee

anchor.surface_text: Before setting out these details, it would be convenient... the economic implications of forward trading in commodities, the need for the regulation of such trading

holdings.text: Sections 5, 6 and 10 of the Act do not infringe the freedom guaranteed by sub-cl. (c) of cl. (1) of Art. 19 of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Restrictions apply only to voluntary recognition seekers; no constitutional right to recognition; regulation of forward trading legitimate via voluntary associations; cites All India Bank Employees Association.

holdings.text: Existence of a recognised association is not a prerequisite for issuing a notification under s.15(1) of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No express or implicit condition in s.15(1); s.17 allows prohibition without association; Act cannot be defeated by non-formation of associations.

holdings.text: Issuing notification under s.15 without prior recognition of association is not an unreasonable restriction under Art.19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: In situations like those here the reasonableness of the restriction has necessarily to be tested by the degree of urgency which required the intervention of Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Urgency from price rise justified immediate action before recognition formalities; balances public interest against individual rights; no mala fides.

holdings.text: Section 15 does not infringe Article 14 of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Guidance from variable economic factors, expert advice of Forward Markets Commission; commodities and timing not static; Ch.II provides machinery.

holdings.text: Section 15 does not violate Art.19(1)(f) or (g); retrospective invalidation of contracts is not per se unreasonable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No constitutional bar like US contract clause; retrospective effect factor in reasonableness test, not fatal; public interest in price stability; cites precedents on reasonableness.

holdings.text: Section 15 of the Act is constitutionally valid.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Restrictions reasonable under Art.19(5),(6); public interest in stable prices for essential commodity; expert machinery ensures validity.

holdings.text: Section 16 of the Act is not invalid for excessive delegation or violation of Art.14.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Implicit guidance of reasonableness and market factors; analogous to Essential Commodities Act s.3; fixation based on 3-month average reasonable, counters speculation.

holdings.text: The notification under s.16 fixing closing out rates is valid and reasonable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Average of 3-month closing rates reasonable given rigged prices; prevents manipulation; complies with Art.19(6).

holdings.text: The operative provisions of the Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952 are constitutionally valid.
holdings.reasoning_summary: All specific challenges to ss.5,6,10,15,16 rejected; regulation of forward trading legitimate for public interest; passes Art.14,19 tests.

precedents.cited_proposition: content and scope of the freedom of association guaranteed by Article 19(1)(c) of the Constitution in light of other freedoms under Article 19(1)

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose
precedents.cited_proposition: retrospective operation of a statute is a factor to be considered in determining the reasonableness of the restriction imposed
precedents.cited_holding: the fact that the statute was being given retrospective operation may properly be taken into consideration in determining the reasonableness of the restriction imposed

precedents.citation: Express News papers Private Ltd. v. Union of India  1

anchor.surface_text: Express News papers Private Ltd. v. Union of India  1 . The decisions referred to and others to a like effect are authorities merely for the position that the retrospective effect of a statute would be an element to be taken into account for determining the reasonableness of the restriction imposed

precedents.case_name: Express Newspapers Private Ltd. v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: retrospective effect of a statute is an element in assessing reasonableness of restrictions under Article 19

precedents.citation: Atlantic, Coast Line, Co. v. Goldsboro  1

anchor.surface_text: Atlantic, Coast Line, Co. v. Goldsboro  1  companytinues In the words of the Court ,It is settled that neither the companytract clause number the due process clause has the effect of overriding the power of the State to establish all regulations that are reasonably necessary to secure the health, safety, good order, companyfort, or general welfare of the companymunity

precedents.case_name: Atlantic Coast Line Co. v. Goldsboro
precedents.cited_proposition: contract clause or due process does not override state police power for reasonable regulations necessary for public welfare
precedents.cited_holding: neither the contract clause nor the due process clause has the effect of overriding the power of the State to establish all regulations that are reasonably necessary to secure the health, safety, good order, comfort, or general welfare of the community

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. V. G. Row

anchor.surface_text: State of Madras v. V. G. Row It is important in this companytext to bear in mind that the test of reasonableness, wherever prescribed, should be applied to each individual statute impugned, and numberabstract , standard, or general pattern of reasonableness can be laid down as applicable to all cases.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. V. G. Row
precedents.cited_proposition: test of reasonableness under Article 19 must consider nature of right, purpose of restriction, urgency of evil, disproportion, prevailing conditions
precedents.cited_holding: the test of reasonableness... should all enter into the judicial verdict

anchor.surface_text: We see, therefore, no sufficient ground for holding that the power conferred on the Central Government to fix the price at which contracts could be closed out is either legislatively incompetent or constitutionally invalid.
